author: tombrandstarkware
content:
What do you see as the biggest motivation for account abstraction in Ethereum?
I think it is easy to see why signature abstraction is a desired property, but the other use cases are still vague for mee

author: lightclient
content: permissionless innovation is desirable, there are lots of smart people out there who will take AA and do things we can't imagine

author: tombrandstarkware
content: This is indeed a good reason

author: lightclient
content: practically, AA can help reduce the amount of "failed" txs on-chain but that pass the protocol validity checks (e.g. failed uniswap tx)

author: lightclient
content: additionally, it can help remove intermediaries that forming around ethereum like tx relayers (this is particularly useful for privacy preserving applications like tornado cash)

author: tombrandstarkware
content: Could you elaborate on it - why is that?

author: lightclient
content: AA abstraction provides "validity abstraction" for txs - this means you can write arbitrary code to determine if a tx is valid, no longer relying only on sig + nonce + balance. This means an AA account could check that txs to it are "successful" on uniswap and if so consider them valid. Consider invalid in all other cases. If the tx is considered invalid by the AA contract the tx *cannot* be included in a block, it's equivalent to including a tx in a block without enough balance for gas - it makes the full block invalid

author: tombrandstarkware
content: I see.. so it allows a user to save gas (and Ethereum block space) by invalidating txs based on arbitrary logic.
